ygData.subject: HyperNEAT: Creating Neural Networks with CPPNs
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi everyone, as some of you know, we have been working for a while now on turning the patterns output by CPPNs into neural networks. I am excited to report

Subject: HyperNEAT: Creating Neural Networks with CPPNs
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=1k4XFjpFiXpqXiVSaf8URSnWnCbuDi4doeQpgkuiDQDGH8DhIYir
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

Hi everyone, as some of you know, we have been working for a while 
now on =
turning the patterns output by CPPNs into neural networks.  

I am excited =
to report that we have found a 
straightforward and principled approach to =
interpreting CPPN output 
as a connectivity pattern rather than a spatial p=
attern.    We are 
calling this method HyperNEAT, which stands for Hypercub=
e-based 
NEAT.  With HyperNEAT, we have been able to produce working neural=
 
networks with millions of connections.

Because we have just recently had=
 two publications on this method 
accepted at GECCO-2007, we can finally di=
sclose our work and share 
it with others.  The publications are available =
on 
the "Publications" page at http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu 

They are also avai=
lable through my homepage 
http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#publications (u=
nder Publications, 
Conference and Symposium Papers), or directly at the fo=
llowing 
address, which I am sure yahoo is going to mangle:

http://eplex.c=
s.ucf.edu/index.php?
option=3Dcom_content&task=3Dview&id=3D14&Itemid=3D28

=
The two papers, which present separate experiments are:

"Generating Large-=
Scale Neural Networks Through Discovering 
Geometric Regularities" by Jason=
 J. Gauci and Kenneth O. Stanley

and 

"A Novel Generative Encoding for Ex=
ploiting Neural Network Sensor 
and Output Geometry" by David B. D'Ambrosio=
 and Kenneth O. Stanley

David D'Ambriosio and Jason Gauci are both Ph.D. s=
tudents in the 
EPlex lab who did an enormous amount of work to make this p=
ossible.

HyperNEAT is based on a surprisingly simple principle: Connectivi=
ty 
patterns are actually no different from spatial patterns in a higher-
d=
imensional space.  In other words, a 2-dimensional connectivity 
pattern is=
 the same thing as a 4-dimensional spatial pattern.  (The 
technical term i=
s that they are "isomorphic.")  Therefore, if we 
simply produce spatial pa=
tterns within a 4D hypercube instead of a 
2D plane, they can be mapped dir=
ectly to connectivity patterns with 
all the nice properties that we have s=
een from CPPNs.  Thus, they 
require no special "image recognition" type tr=
icks.  The mapping is 
perfectly isomorphic.  We are calling these 4D CPPNs=
 "connective 
CPPNs" since they are interpreted as connectivity patterns.

=
This insight yields a handful of unprecedented capabilities.  For 
example,=
 with connective CPPNs, you can recreate the same solution 
network at a di=
fferent resolution without further evolution!  You 
can also place inputs a=
nd outputs in meaningful geometric 
configurations that HyperNEAT can explo=
it for symmetries and 
regularities.  

In any case, I am excited about thi=
s new advance and these papers 
are a first step in exploring the new appro=
ach.

ken
